\begin{abstract}

We show that estimates of the Lorentz symmetry violation 
extracted from ultra-high energy cosmic rays beyond the GZK cut-off 
set bounds on the parameters of a Lorentz-violating extension 
of the Standard Model. Moreover, we 
argue that correlated measurements of the difference in the
arrival time of gamma-ray photons and neutrinos emitted from
Active Galactic Nuclei or Gamma-Ray Bursts may provide a signature
for a possible violation of the Lorentz symmetry. We find
that this time delay is energy independent, but that it has a dependence 
on the chirality of the particles involved. 

\end{abstract}

\section{INTRODUCTION}

Lorentz invariance is one of the most fundamental symmetries of physics and 
is an underlying ingredient of all known physical theories. However, more 
recently, there has been theoretical evidence that, in the realm of 
string/M-theory, this symmetry may be violated. 
This naturally poses the question of verifying this violation 
experimentally.
